author: Potter
text: It is said that the effect of eating too much lettuce is "soporific."

author: Potter
text: I have never felt sleepy after eating lettuces; but then I am not a rabbit.

author: Potter
text: They certainly had a very soporific effect upon the Flopsy Bunnies!

author: Potter
text: When Benjamin Bunny grew up, he married his Cousin Flopsy.

author: Potter
text: They had a large family, and they were very improvident and cheerful.

author: Potter
text: I do not remember the separate names of their children; they were generally called the "Flopsy Bunnies."

author: Potter
text: As there was not always quite enough to eat,--Benjamin used to borrow cabbages from Flopsy's brother, Peter Rabbit, who kept a nursery garden.

author: Potter
text: Sometimes Peter Rabbit had no cabbages to spare.

author: Potter
text: When this happened, the Flopsy Bunnies went across the field to a rubbish heap, in the ditch outside Mr. McGregor's garden.

author: Potter
text: Mr. McGregor's rubbish heap was a mixture.

author: Potter
text: There were jam pots and paper bags, and mountains of chopped grass from the mowing machine (which always tasted oily), and some rotten vegetable marrows and an old boot or two.

author: Potter
text: One day--oh joy!--there were a quantity of overgrown lettuces, which had "shot" into flower.

author: Potter
text: The Flopsy Bunnies simply stuffed themselves with lettuces.

author: Potter
text: By degrees, one after another, they were overcome with slumber, and lay down in the mown grass.

author: Potter
text: Benjamin was not so much overcome as his children.

author: Potter
text: Before going to sleep he was sufficiently wide awake to put a paper bag over his head to keep off the flies.

author: Potter
text: The little Flopsy Bunnies slept delightfully in the warm sun.

author: Potter
text: From the lawn beyond the garden came the distant clacketty sound of the mowing machine.

author: Potter
text: The blue- bottles buzzed about the wall, and a little old mouse picked over the rubbish among the jam pots.

author: Potter
text: (I can tell you her name, she was called Thomasina Tittle- mouse, a woodmouse with a long tail.)

author: Potter
text: She rustled across the paper bag, and awakened Benjamin Bunny.

author: Potter
text: The mouse apologized profusely, and said that she knew Peter Rabbit.

author: Potter
text: While she and Benjamin were talking, close under the wall, they heard a heavy tread above their heads; and suddenly Mr. McGregor emptied out a sackful of lawn mowings right upon the top of the sleeping Flopsy Bunnies!

author: Potter
text: Benjamin shrank down under his paper bag.

author: Potter
text: The mouse hid in a jam pot.

author: Potter
text: The little rabbits smiled sweetly in their sleep under the shower of grass; they did not awake because the lettuces had been so soporific.

author: Potter
text: They dreamt that their mother Flopsy was tucking them up in a hay bed.

author: Potter
text: Mr. McGregor looked down after emptying his sack.

author: Potter
text: He saw some funny little brown tips of ears sticking up through the lawn mowings.

author: Potter
text: He stared at them for some time.

author: Potter
text: Presently a fly settled on one of them and it moved.

author: Potter
text: Mr. McGregor climbed down on to the rubbish heap--

author: Potter
text: "One, two, three, four! five! six leetle rabbits!" said he as he dropped them into his sack.

author: Potter
text: The Flopsy Bunnies dreamt that their mother was turning them over in bed.

author: Potter
text: They stirred a little in their sleep, but still they did not wake up.

author: Potter
text: Mr. McGregor tied up the sack and left it on the wall.

author: Potter
text: He went to put away the mowing machine.

author: Potter
text: While he was gone, Mrs. Flopsy Bunny (who had remained at home) came across the field.

author: Potter
text: She looked suspiciously at the sack and wondered where everybody was?

author: Potter
text: Then the mouse came out of her jam pot, and Benjamin took the paper bag off his head, and they told the doleful tale.

author: Potter
text: Benjamin and Flopsy were in despair, they could not undo the string.

author: Potter
text: But Mrs. Tittlemouse was a resourceful person.

author: Potter
text: She nibbled a hole in the bottom corner of the sack.

author: Potter
text: The little rabbits were pulled out and pinched to wake them.

author: Potter
text: Their parents stuffed the empty sack with three rotten vegetable marrows, an old blackingbrush and two decayed turnips.

author: Potter
text: Then they all hid under a bush and watched for Mr. McGregor.

author: Potter
text: Mr. McGregor came back and picked up the sack, and carried it off.

author: Potter
text: He carried it hanging down, as if it were rather heavy.

author: Potter
text: The Flopsy Bunnies followed at a safe distance.

author: Potter
text: They watched him go into his house.

author: Potter
text: And then they crept up to the window to listen.

author: Potter
text: Mr. McGregor threw down the sack on the stone floor in a way that would have been extremely painful to the Flopsy Bunnies, if they had happened to have been inside it.

author: Potter
text: They could hear him drag his chair on the flags, and chuckle--

author: Potter
text: "One, two, three, four, five, six leetle rabbits!" said Mr. McGregor.

author: Potter
text: "Eh?

author: Potter
text: What's that?

author: Potter
text: What have they been spoiling now?" enquired Mrs. McGregor.

author: Potter
text: "One, two, three, four, five, six leetle fat rabbits!" repeated Mr. McGregor, counting on his fingers --"one, two, three--"

author: Potter
text: "Don't you be silly: what do you mean, you silly old man?"

author: Potter
text: "In the sack! one, two, three, four, five, six!" replied Mr. McGregor.

author: Potter
text: (The youngest Flopsy Bunny got upon the windowsill.)

author: Potter
text: Mrs. McGregor took hold of the sack and felt it.

author: Potter
text: She said she could feel six, but they must be OLD rabbits, because they were so hard and all different shapes.

author: Potter
text: "Not fit to eat; but the skins will do fine to line my old cloak."

author: Potter
text: "Line your old cloak?" shouted Mr. McGregor--"I shall sell them and buy myself baccy!"

author: Potter
text: "Rabbit tobacco!

author: Potter
text: I shall skin them and cut off their heads."

author: Potter
text: Mrs. McGregor untied the sack and put her hand inside.

author: Potter
text: When she felt the vegetables she became very very angry.

author: Potter
text: She said that Mr. McGregor had "done it a purpose."

author: Potter
text: And Mr. McGregor was very angry too.

author: Potter
text: One of the rotten marrows came flying through the kitchen window, and hit the youngest Flopsy Bunny.

author: Potter
text: It was rather hurt.

author: Potter
text: Then Benjamin and Flopsy thought that it was time to go home.

author: Potter
text: So Mr. McGregor did not get his tobacco, and Mrs. McGregor did not get her rabbit skins.

author: Potter
text: But next Christmas Thomasina Tittlemouse got a present of enough rabbit wool to make herself a cloak and a hood, and a handsome muff and a pair of warm mittens.
